title: 10 Reasons Why Students Are Becoming More Lazy To Study
author: ACHSOSA '93 Alumni
excerpt: This article explores why modern students are increasingly losing the drive to study, citing distractions like social media, poor study habits, and lack of motivation. It also highlights what parents, teachers, and governments can do to restore the culture of learning.
content:
In recent years, educators and parents around the world have noticed a worrying trend: many students seem to be losing interest in studying. Laziness toward learning is becoming more common, leading to poor academic performance, lack of critical thinking, and even low self-motivation in life. While technology, lifestyle changes, and social influences are major contributors, there are deeper issues at play. Below are ten reasons why students are becoming more lazy to study, followed by possible solutions that government, parents, and educators can take to reverse this trend.

1. Distractions from Technology

Smartphones, video games, and social media have become irresistible distractions. Instead of focusing on schoolwork, many students spend hours scrolling, chatting, or gaming.

2. Lack of Clear Goals

When students cannot see the long-term benefit of education, they lose motivation. Many no longer connect studying with their future success.

3. Poor Time Management

Students often procrastinate, leaving assignments until the last minute. This leads to stress, poor results, and an even greater dislike for studying.

4. Overdependence on Shortcuts

With Google and AI tools, many students expect instant answers. This reduces their willingness to engage in deep reading or critical thinking.

5. Peer Influence

When friends do not value education, students may follow the same pattern, thinking studying is uncool or unnecessary.

6. Lack of Encouragement at Home

In many families, parents are too busy or uninvolved to supervise homework or encourage good study habits.

7. Weak Study Environment

Noise, lack of access to libraries, and absence of quiet places make concentration difficult for many learners.

8. Poor Teaching Methods

Some students lose interest because teaching styles are boring, outdated, or not interactive enough to keep them engaged.

9. Mental Health Challenges

Anxiety, stress, and depression are on the rise among young people, making studying seem like an extra burden rather than an opportunity.

10. Overloaded Curriculum

In some schools, the curriculum is too heavy, leaving students drained and uninterested in studying further outside the classroom.

How to Reverse This Trend

While the problem of student laziness is complex, it is not impossible to solve. It requires a joint effort from governments, parents, and educators to restore the culture of discipline and passion for learning.

Role of Government:

  • Provide modern learning infrastructure such as digital libraries, labs, and interactive classrooms.
  • Review and update the curriculum to make it more practical and skill-oriented rather than purely theoretical.
  • Support campaigns that highlight the importance of education and reduce societal distractions that undermine learning.

Role of Parents:

  • Monitor children’s screen time and encourage a balance between entertainment and academics.
  • Create a study-friendly environment at home with less noise and more encouragement.
  • Lead by example by showing a positive attitude toward lifelong learning.

Role of Educators:

  • Adopt modern teaching methods that are interactive, technology-driven, and student-centered.
  • Encourage project-based learning and teamwork to make studying more practical and enjoyable.
  • Mentor students not only academically but also morally, motivating them to see the value of education in real life.

Conclusion

Students today face more distractions and challenges than ever before, but laziness to study should not define their future. With combined support from governments, parents, and educators, it is possible to bring back the era when learning was a priority and a source of pride. The responsibility lies with all of us to make studying meaningful again and to ensure that the next generation is well-prepared for the future.

title: Best Methods to Read and Assimilate
author: EduConnect
excerpt: Discover practical study techniques tailored for primary, secondary, and higher education students. From active recall to spaced repetition, this article draws on proven strategies and educational philosophies to help learners retain knowledge and excel academically.
content:
Reading and assimilation are not just academic skills; they are life-long habits that determine how effectively a student learns, remembers, and applies knowledge. In today’s fast-paced world where distractions are everywhere, the ability to read deeply and assimilate effectively has become more important than ever. Whether a child is in primary school, a teenager in secondary school, or a young adult in higher education, good reading and learning strategies are critical.

1. Primary School Level
At the primary level, children are just developing foundational skills. Their ability to focus is short, so methods must be engaging and playful. Teachers and parents should introduce phonics, storytelling, and reading aloud. These methods not only build word recognition but also improve comprehension. Picture books with bold illustrations stimulate the imagination and improve memory. A key strategy here is guided repetition. Children learn faster when stories are repeated in creative ways, such as role-playing. As the educational philosopher Maria Montessori once said: The goal of early childhood education should be to activate the child’s own natural desire to learn.

2. Secondary School Level
At this stage, students are exposed to more complex texts and are expected to study independently. Unfortunately, distractions from social media and peer pressure often make this difficult. To improve assimilation, students should adopt the Pomodoro technique—25 minutes of focused study followed by a 5-minute break. Note-taking strategies like Cornell notes and mind mapping help in organizing thoughts. Group study sessions can be beneficial, but they must be structured to prevent idle talk. Encouraging self-discipline is essential, echoing John Dewey’s philosophy that: Education is not preparation for life; education is life itself.

3. Higher Institution of Learning
In universities and colleges, reading goes beyond understanding—it requires critical analysis and application. Students must learn to filter through large amounts of information, highlight key points, and relate theories to practical examples. Advanced strategies such as SQ3R (Survey, Question, Read, Recite, Review) help in breaking down textbooks into manageable parts. Assimilation improves when students engage in discussions, debates, and presentations. Effective time management and creating a distraction-free environment are also vital. As Paulo Freire wrote in Pedagogy of the Oppressed: Education either functions as an instrument to facilitate integration of the younger generation into the logic of the present system or becomes the practice of freedom.

General Assimilation Techniques
Across all levels, there are universal strategies that improve reading and assimilation:

  • Reading in a quiet, well-lit environment
  • Writing summaries in your own words
  • Using flashcards for key concepts
  • Teaching what you’ve learned to others
  • Sleeping well after studying to reinforce memory

The Role of Parents, Teachers, and Institutions
Parents should encourage daily reading culture at home, limit screen time, and create routines. Teachers must make learning interactive and engaging, ensuring students remain active participants. Schools and governments can provide libraries, digital resources, and training on study skills. Together, they can revive a culture of reading where learning is prioritized above distractions.

In conclusion, reading and assimilation are not talents reserved for a few—they are skills that can be developed with the right approach. By combining discipline, creativity, and effective strategies, students at all levels can master the art of learning and secure their path to excellence. As Aristotle famously said: The roots of education are bitter, but the fruit is sweet.

title: Exercises Needed To Enhance Study Assimilation
excerpt: Discover the role of physical and mental exercises in improving memory, focus, and study assimilation for students of all ages.
content:
Studying is more than just reading books; it’s about how well the brain can retain, process, and recall information. Many students often struggle with assimilation, not because they lack intelligence, but because they do not adopt the right practices to strengthen their memory and concentration. One powerful way to improve study assimilation is through physical and mental exercises. Research has shown that incorporating certain habits into your daily routine can sharpen your brain, increase focus, and make learning more enjoyable.

1. Morning Stretch and Breathing Exercises

Starting your day with light stretching and controlled breathing helps improve blood circulation to the brain. Oxygen flow increases mental clarity, reduces stress, and prepares you for a productive study session. Even five minutes of deep breathing before opening your books can boost focus levels.

2. Aerobic Exercises

Simple activities like jogging, brisk walking, skipping, or cycling play a significant role in improving memory. Aerobic exercises increase heart rate, which in turn stimulates the release of chemicals that enhance brain function. Students who engage in aerobic workouts three to four times a week often show better performance in exams.

3. Yoga and Meditation

Yoga is more than a physical exercise—it combines balance, flexibility, and mindfulness. The meditative aspect helps students calm their minds, eliminate distractions, and improve assimilation. Poses like the Lotus and Tree Pose enhance both concentration and posture, making long study hours easier to endure.

4. Brain Training Games

Mental exercises are just as important as physical ones. Puzzles, Sudoku, memory games, and coding activities strengthen the brain’s processing speed. They keep the mind sharp and flexible, ensuring that new information is absorbed more quickly.

5. Regular Breaks and Active Learning

The brain assimilates information better when study sessions are spaced out with breaks. Short walks, stretches, or even dancing between reading sessions refresh the brain and improve retention. Active learning—like explaining what you learned to a friend—also doubles memory recall.

6. Hydration and Nutrition

Although not an exercise in the strict sense, drinking enough water and eating brain-boosting foods such as nuts, fish, and fruits play a huge role in mental clarity. Dehydration can cause fatigue and low concentration, while healthy meals keep the brain active.

Conclusion

Enhancing study assimilation is about adopting a lifestyle that balances both mind and body. From morning stretches to yoga, brain games, and healthy routines, students who consistently practice these exercises will not only assimilate better but also develop habits that promote lifelong learning.

title: The World And Tech: Call To Switch Career At Early Stage—Or Blend With The Trend
excerpt: Technology is reshaping the world, forcing young professionals to rethink careers. Should you switch early or blend tech into your path?
content:
Technology is changing the way we live, work, and interact. The rise of artificial intelligence, robotics, data science, and digital platforms has redefined almost every industry. Today, individuals are faced with an important question: should they switch careers into technology at an early stage, or simply blend their chosen paths with modern tech trends?

The Pace of Change

Just two decades ago, careers in tech were limited mostly to computer engineers and IT specialists. Now, fields such as finance, healthcare, education, agriculture, and even art are deeply integrated with technology. This pace of change means that professionals who adapt early gain a competitive advantage in the global economy.

Switching Careers Early

For many young professionals and students, switching to a tech-driven career offers long-term benefits. Careers in software engineering, cybersecurity, cloud computing, and AI are not only high-paying but also future-proof. Early switchers can build foundational knowledge that keeps them relevant for decades.

Blending With The Trend

However, switching is not always necessary. For instance, a teacher can blend technology into their career by learning how to use digital tools for online education. A farmer can integrate data-driven apps to monitor soil and weather conditions. A marketer can blend traditional advertising skills with digital marketing expertise. In reality, the blend approach works for people who already love their fields but want to remain competitive.

Challenges of Switching

Switching careers may come with challenges—extra training, certifications, and the discomfort of starting fresh. But those who overcome these hurdles often find themselves more versatile and employable. The short-term struggle leads to long-term stability.

Opportunities in Blending

Blending is less disruptive and often more practical. It allows professionals to keep their passion while using technology to expand their impact. A doctor using telemedicine, or an artist using digital tools, can thrive without abandoning their original calling.

The Future Belongs To The Flexible

The key lesson is that the future belongs to those who are flexible. Whether you choose to switch early or blend, what matters most is being open to continuous learning. With online platforms offering free and affordable courses, there are fewer excuses for remaining outdated.

Conclusion

In today’s world, ignoring technology is not an option. Young people must decide whether to take the leap into a full career switch or enrich their chosen fields with tech innovations. Either way, the goal is the same—remain relevant, employable, and innovative in a rapidly changing world.
